Award.AwardTitle: Support for the 16th Annual Black Graduate Conference for Students in Psychology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: This is a proposal for support of a conference. It is a request for a small amount of funds to support the 16th Annual Black Graduate Conference in Psychology (BGCP). Since 1995, the BGCP has contributed to the scholarly and career development of over 650 participants by: (1) improving the research capabilities of graduate students by providing them with a supportive atmosphere in which to present their research and receive constructive feedback; (2) providing graduate students with an opportunity to exchange strategies and experiences that will help them to thrive in graduate school and beyond; and (3)providing a forum for graduate students in psychology to network and develop collaborative relationships with future colleagues. The activities proposed are designed to provide a sustained approach to the training of African American graduate students in psychology. As one of the few venues for examining the psychological experiences of African Americans, the conference serves as an important incubator for new ideas in the field. These new ideas not only benefit the study of African Americans, but also enhance the field of psychology as a whole. Additional broader impacts of the conference include its important role in: (1) retaining African American students in psychology graduate programs, and (2) developing psychologists at top-tier research institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since 1995, the Black Graduate Conference in Psychology (BGCP) has been held on an annual basis and has contributed to the scholarly and career development of over 700 participants.  The 16th Annual BGCP was held July 8-11, 2010 and hosted by the University of Maryland, Baltimore County. An opening reception was held on June 10 in which several university administrators - including President Freeman Hrabowski and Provost Elliot Hirshman - greeted the attendees and faculty mentors.  Conference attendees experienced a career development panel that featured six junior faculty from liberal arts and research-intensive institutions.  Representatives from the Ford Foundation and the National Institutes of Drug Abuse delivered a mini-workshop on funding opportunities at the predoctoral, postdoctoral, and early career levels.  In addition to more than 25 research posters, there were also 8 outstanding paper presentations presented over two days that represented a breadth of topics in educational, social, community, developmental, and health psychology.  The conference culminated with a banquet that featured a keynote address from Dr. Cheryl Grills, chair of the psychology department at Loyola University.  Overall, attendees indicated highly favorable ratings of the conference: 100% of student attendees indicated that they had learned new information that could improve their scholarly or research activities.  They were impressed with the conference's organization, collegial atmosphere, and scientific rigor.  Other evaluation material demonstrates that the conference organizers achieved their goals of providing graduate students with: (1) a supportive atmosphere in which to present their research and receive constructive feedback; (2)  an opportunity to exchange strategies and experiences that will help them to thrive in graduate school and beyond; and (3) an environment in which to network and develop collaborative relationships with future colleagues.
